english_translation: Mujahid said regarding the verse 'Fulfill the contracts' (Al-Maidah 5:1): They mean the covenants.

potential_issues.issue: Maqtu' hadith: The chain terminates at Mujahid (second generation tafsir scholar), not reaching the Prophet ﷺ
potential_issues.impact: This is an explanatory hadith (tafsir) rather than a prophetic statement, making it maqtu'. While the narrators are generally reliable, the nature of disconnection affects its classification as not marfu'.

potential_issues.issue: Warqa's ikhtilat: Warqa ibn Uthman is known to have experienced confusion (ikhtilat) in his later years
potential_issues.impact: Moderate impact - transmission likely pre-dates his confusion given the reliability of other narrators in the chain, but this should be noted.

potential_issues.issue: Indirect transmission terms from Ibn Abi Najah and Mujahid
potential_issues.impact: While Ibn Abi Najah and Mujahid consistently use 'an in their tafsir transmissions, this is typical for exegetical materials and does not significantly impact reliability given their established reputations.

Topics: Meaning of covenants ('ahd) in Islamic jurisprudence

english_translation: Mujahid said regarding the verse 'Lawful to you are the animals of livestock' (Al-Maidah 5:1): What is mentioned with it except that hunting is unlawful while in ihram (sacred state).

Topics: Quranic interpretation of 'Lawful to you are the animals of livestock' (Al-Maidah 5:1)

Explanation of permitted and forbidden game

english_translation: Mujahid said regarding the verse on 'garlands' (Al-Maidah 5:2): The stitching on the necks of people and animals is a safety for them. They are from the signs of Allah. The signs are: the sacrificial animal, the garlands, the Safa and Marwa, and the sacrificial cattle. All of this is from the signs of Allah. This is because the Companions of the Prophet ﷺ were saying this is from the deeds of the time of ignorance in its performance and establishment. But it was permissible in Islam except the garlands and the stitching, for that is avoidance.

chainIssues: Chain stops at Abu Salamah level (tabi'i or atba' al-tabi'in), making it maqtu' (disconnected)

Warqa has reported ikhtilat in later life

potential_issues.impact: This significantly weakens the chain. An unknown narrator in the chain raises questions about reliability. The identity and reliability of Abu Salamah cannot be established.
The chain stops at an unknown narrator (Abu Salamah), making it maqtu' with questionable reliability at the endpoint.

potential_issues.issue: Transmission terminology becomes less direct from Ibn Abi Najah onwards
potential_issues.impact: The shift from direct (ثنا) to less direct terms (عَنِ, قَالَ, عَنْ) suggests increasing remoteness in transmission.
Known confusion in later years requires verification of when this narration was transmitted.

Explanation of ritual symbols (Safa, Marwa, sacrificial animals)
Companions' discussion of pre-Islamic practices and their permissibility in Islam

english_translation: Mujahid said regarding the verse 'and do not approach the Sacred House while in a state of ihram, seeking bounty from your Lord' (Al-Maidah 5:2): They mean commerce. And 'and seeking His pleasure' (Al-Maidah 5:2): They mean the reward. Allah has forbidden to everyone frightening them.

english_translation: Mujahid said regarding the verse 'and do not transgress' (Al-Maidah 5:2): That is because a believing man from among the allies of the allies of the Prophet ﷺ killed an ally of Abu Sufyan from Hudhail on the day of the Conquest at Arafah, because he was killing the allies of the Prophet ﷺ. So the Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'Allah has cursed whoever kills with a grievance of the time of ignorance.'

Companions' behavior during the Conquest of Makkah

english_translation: Mujahid said regarding the verse 'and whatever has been sacrificed on the idols' (Al-Maidah 5:3): Those are stones which were around the Kaaba. The people of the time of ignorance used to sacrifice for them, and they would change them whenever they wished, and whenever they saw something more desirable to them than them.

english_translation: Mujahid said regarding the verse 'and that you cast lots by arrows' (Al-Maidah 5:3): Those are gambling arrows. They would strike them for every journey, expedition, and commerce.

english_translation: Mujahid said regarding the verse 'The food of those who have been given the Scripture is lawful for you' (Al-Maidah 5:5): This means their slaughtered animals are lawful for you.

english_translation: Mujahid said regarding the verse 'And if you are ill' (Al-Maidah 5:6): This means the one with pustules, and the one with wounds, and the one with injuries who fears for himself if he washes or performs ablution that he will die, so these people perform Tayammum. [Also narrated with another chain]: I was serving the Messenger of Allah ﷺ when Gabriel brought the verse of dirt-based purification. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ showed me how to wipe for Tayammum. I struck my hands on the earth, then wiped my face with them, then struck my hands on the earth, then wiped my arms to the elbows.

narrators.name: Abd al-Rahman
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn al-Husayn ibn Muhammad ibn Ja'far al-Shibaani
narrators.alternative_names: Muhammad ibn al-Husayn al-Shibaani, Abu al-Fath al-Shibaani, Abu al-Fath

narrators.name: Ibrahim al-Saji
narrators.full_name: Ibrahim ibn Fahl ibn Hakim ibn Ibrahim ibn Qudamah ibn Mahan
narrators.alternative_names: Ibrahim ibn Fahl al-Basri, Abu Ishaq al-Saji, Abu Ishaq

narrators.name: Adam
narrators.full_name: Adam ibn Abi Iyas al-Awdi
narrators.alternative_names: Adam ibn Abi Iyas, Abu Muhammad al-Awdi

narrators.name: al-Rabi' ibn Badr
narrators.full_name: al-Rabi' ibn Badr ibn Uthman
narrators.alternative_names: al-Rabi' ibn Badr, Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn Musa

narrators.name: Ishaq ibn Ibrahim
narrators.full_name: Ishaq ibn Ibrahim ibn Yazid al-Damaschi
narrators.alternative_names: Ishaq ibn Yazid, Abu al-Nadr al-Faradeesi, Abu al-Nadr

narrators.name: Ubaid ibn al-Wasim
narrators.full_name: Ubaid ibn al-Wasim al-Bakri
narrators.alternative_names: Ubaid ibn al-Wasim, Ubaid ibn Wasim al-Jamal, Abu al-Wasim

narrators.name: Ayyub ibn Sulayman (al-Aslaa')
narrators.full_name: Ayyub ibn Sulayman al-Basri
reliabilityIssues: Identity unclear - only identified as al-Aslaa' in text
narrators.alternative_names: Ayyub ibn Sulayman al-Basri, Abu Sulayman al-Maktab, Abu Sulayman, al-Aslaa'

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim
narrators.alternative_names: Ahmad, al-Mustafa, Muhammad ﷺ

chainIssues: Second chain reaches the Prophet ﷺ through al-Aslaa' who claimed to be the Prophet's servant
al-Aslaa' (Ayyub ibn Sulayman) is majhul (unknown) - identity and reliability cannot be established
Chain has mixed transmission terms: direct (نا, ثنا) then indirect (عَنْ, قَالَ)
Use of indirect terms (عَنْ) from Ishaq and Ubaid

potential_issues.issue: Chain 1: Ata ibn al-Sa'ib's ikhtilat (confusion) - highly problematic narrator
potential_issues.impact: Ata ibn al-Sa'ib is known to have experienced significant confusion (ikhtilat) in later life, making his transmissions unreliable. This chain appears suspect.

potential_issues.issue: Chain 2: al-Aslaa' (Ayyub ibn Sulayman) is Majhul (unknown)
potential_issues.impact: This severely weakens the second chain. An unknown narrator at the endpoint makes verification of the Prophet's statement impossible. Even if he served the Prophet, his identity and reliability cannot be established.

potential_issues.issue: Hadith contains two different chains with different endpoints
potential_issues.impact: Chain 1 is maqtu' (stops at tabi'i), Chain 2 claims to be marfu' but relies on unknown narrator (al-Aslaa'). This creates significant reliability issues.

Topics: Quranic interpretation of 'And if you are ill' (Al-Maidah 5:6)
Description of persons permitted to perform Tayammum: those with pustules, wounds, and injuries
Incident where the Prophet ﷺ taught the method of Tayammum
Gabriel bringing the verse of Tayammum (dirt-based purification)
Method of performing Tayammum as taught by the Prophet ﷺ

english_translation: Mujahid said regarding the verse 'from hardship' (Al-Maidah 5:6): He means from narrowness/difficulty.

narrators.name: Abd al-Rahman
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn al-Husayn ibn Muhammad ibn Ja'far al-Shibaani
narrators.alternative_names: Muhammad ibn al-Husayn al-Shibaani, Abu al-Fath al-Shibaani, Abu al-Fath

narrators.alternative_names: Ibrahim ibn Fahl al-Basri, Abu Ishaq al-Saji, Abu Ishaq

narrators.name: Adam

narrators.alternative_names: Adam ibn Abi Iyas, Abu Muhammad al-Awdi

narrators.name: Warqa

narrators.alternative_names: Warqa ibn Uthman al-Zurqi, Abu Uthman al-Madani, Abu Uthman

narrators.name: Ibn Abi Najah
narrators.full_name: Shafi ibn Ma'ta al-Asbahi
narrators.alternative_names: Shafi ibn Ma'ta, Shafi ibn Abdullah al-Masri, Abu Uthman, Abu Sahel, Abu Ubaid

narrators.name: Mujahid
narrators.full_name: Mujahid ibn Jabr al-Ammi al-Makki
narrators.alternative_names: Mujahid ibn Jabr, Abu al-Hajjaj al-Makki, Abu al-Hajjaj

chainIssues: Chain stops at Mujahid (tabi'i), making it maqtu' (disconnected)
Warqa has reported ikhtilat in later life

potential_issues.issue: Maqtu' hadith: Chain stops at Mujahid (tabi'i), not reaching Prophet ﷺ
potential_issues.impact: This is a tafsir explanation. While narrators are generally reliable, the nature of disconnection affects classification.

english_translation: Mujahid said regarding the verse 'and His covenant which He has made with you' (Al-Maidah 5:7): This means the covenant which He covenanted with the children of Adam in the loins of Adam.

Covenant in the loins of Adam before creation
